case_title: IFTIKHAR AHMAD, ADVOCATE vs ABDUL RAZIQ, ADVOCATE

accussed_details.name: Abdul Raziq
allegation: Violation of cannons of conduct for legal profession

complaint_summary: Iftikhar Ahmad alleged that Abdul Raziq acted both as an eye-witness and as counsel for the prosecution in a bail cancellation application, violating professional conduct rules.
investigation_summary: The Disciplinary Committee recorded evidence, reviewed documents, and referred the case to the Tribunal for final adjudication.
judgment_summary: The Tribunal dismissed the complaint, finding no evidence of professional misconduct. Abdul Raziq's appearance as a court witness was involuntary, and he did not act as counsel in the case after his statement was recorded.
legal_arguments: Rule 157 of Legal Practitioners and Bar Councils Rules, 1976 prohibits an advocate from being a witness for their client except in formal matters.
Section 41 of Legal Practitioners and Bar Councils Act, 1973 provides penalties for professional misconduct.

key_issues: Can an advocate act as both a witness and counsel in the same case?
Violation of Rule 157 of Legal Practitioners and Bar Councils Rules, 1976

maxims.Conflict of interest: An advocate cannot represent conflicting interests in the same case.

legal_terms.Professional misconduct: Violation of ethical standards prescribed for legal practitioners.

summary_vector_notes: The case involved allegations of professional misconduct against Abdul Raziq, Advocate, for acting as both an eye-witness and counsel for the prosecution. The Tribunal found no evidence of misconduct and dismissed the complaint.
